conceptScheme.title: vLEI Ecosystem Governance Framework
conceptScheme.description: Comprehensive governance framework for verifiable Legal Entity Identifiers covering KERI infrastructure, ACDC credentials, organizational roles, and trust assurance.

vlei-ecosystem-governance.definition: A Layer Four Ecosystem Governance Framework of the Trust over IP Foundation that establishes GLEIF's role in digital identity and ACDC Credentials, governing the issuance, holding, and verification of vLEI Credentials through a set of controlled documents covering governance requirements, technical specifications, credential frameworks, and information trust policies.
vlei-ecosystem-governance.scopeNote: Covers the overall framework structure, controlled documents, and change management policies. Does not cover LEI governance processes managed separately by GLEIF.

keri-infrastructure.definition: The decentralized key management and event receipt infrastructure used as the technical foundation for the vLEI Ecosystem, supporting autonomous identifiers, key rotation, witness networks, and cryptographic verification of credential events.
keri-infrastructure.scopeNote: Does not cover credential issuance or schema definitions; those are handled by ACDC and related specifications.

vlei-credentials.definition: A verifiable credential in the vLEI ecosystem implemented as an Authentic Chained Data Container (ACDC) that must support JSON serialization, include SAIDs for immutability, and comply with its specific vLEI Credential Governance Framework.
vlei-credentials.scopeNote: Does not refer to traditional LEI assignments; refers specifically to cryptographically verifiable ACDC-based credentials.

roles-and-representatives.definition: The set of organizational and individual roles within the vLEI Ecosystem, including GLEIF as governing authority, Qualified vLEI Issuers, Legal Entities, their authorized representatives (GARs, QARs, LARs, DARs), and persons holding role credentials (OOR Persons, ECR Persons).
roles-and-representatives.scopeNote: Covers all stakeholder roles and representative functions. Individual credential types are covered under vLEI Credentials.

trust-and-qualification.definition: The trust assurance and qualification domain of the vLEI Ecosystem, encompassing the Trust over IP governance architecture, the Trust Assurance Framework mapping requirements to specification, conformance, and performance assurance, the vLEI Issuer Qualification Program, identity verification processes, risk assessment, and service level management.
trust-and-qualification.scopeNote: Covers trust establishment, qualification of vLEI Issuers, identity verification, and operational assurance. Does not define credential-specific technical requirements.

gleif.definition: A not-for-profit foundation incorporated under Swiss law that operates the Global LEI System and serves as both the Governing Authority and Administering Authority of the vLEI Ecosystem Governance Framework, managing the GLEIF Root AID and overseeing Qualified vLEI Issuers.

global-lei-system.definition: The global system established under the oversight of the Regulatory Oversight Committee for the unique identification of legal entities participating in financial transactions through Legal Entity Identifiers.
global-lei-system.scopeNote: Does not cover the vLEI credential infrastructure; it is the underlying LEI registration and data system.

legal-entity.definition: A legal person or structure organized under the laws of any jurisdiction that is uniquely identified by a Legal Entity Identifier (LEI) as defined in ISO 17442, eligible to receive vLEI Credentials within the vLEI Ecosystem. Includes governmental and supranational organizations but excludes natural persons not acting in a business capacity.
legal-entity.scopeNote: Does not include natural persons acting in their personal capacity; it does include individuals acting in a business capacity.

vlei-ecosystem-information-trust-policie.definition: The suite of information trust policies within the vLEI Ecosystem Governance Framework covering data protection, privacy, security, developer security, incident response, and confidentiality obligations including the Non-Disclosure Agreement between GLEIF and Qualified vLEI Issuers.
vlei-ecosystem-information-trust-policie.scopeNote: Does not include information that is already publicly known, was disclosed without confidentiality reservation, or is required to be disclosed by law.

altLabels: Qualified vLEI Issuer-Legal Entity Required Contract Terms
vlei-issuer-qualification-agreement.definition: The binding legal agreement between GLEIF and a Qualified vLEI Issuer establishing rights and obligations for participation in the vLEI Ecosystem, including core duties, ancillary duties, records management, intellectual property provisions, liability, dispute resolution, third-party services constraints, and Legal Entity contract terms.
vlei-issuer-qualification-agreement.scopeNote: Does not replace the QAR's or LAR's responsibility to verify identity assurance results; the authorized representative must be able to view and confirm the third party's results.

autonomic-identifier.definition: A self-certifying identifier managed via the KERI protocol, existing in two main classes: transferable AIDs supporting key rotation for long-term use, and non-transferable (ephemeral) AIDs that are abandoned upon compromise. Includes delegated AIDs authorized through cooperative cryptographic commitment, and supports DID method resolution via did:keri.
autonomic-identifier.scopeNote: Does not include traditional identifiers such as domain names or URIs that lack self-certifying properties.

key-management.definition: The policies and infrastructure for managing asymmetric key pairs in the vLEI Ecosystem, covering key-pair creation and storage, signature creation using Ed25519, key pre-rotation mechanisms, rotation events, inception events, interaction events, key event logs, and the controller role responsible for authorizing key events.
key-management.scopeNote: Does not involve key rotation; it records non-establishment events such as delegation approvals and credential signings.

witness-and-watcher-network.definition: The decentralized verification infrastructure in KERI consisting of Witness pools that endorse key events using the KERI Algorithm for Witness Agreement (KAWA), Watcher networks that independently verify signature status, and Registrar backers that provide ledger-based secondary roots of trust. Includes GLEIF's own Witness and Watcher networks.
witness-and-watcher-network.scopeNote: Does not have signing authority over credentials; witnesses attest to the receipt of key events but do not authorize credential operations.

delegation-hierarchy.definition: The hierarchical AID structure in the vLEI Ecosystem where the GLEIF Root AID delegates authority to the GLEIF Internal Delegated AID (GIDA) for internal operations and the GLEIF External Delegated AID (GEDA) for issuing QVI credentials, with each delegation requiring cooperative verified signatures from both delegator and delegatee.
delegation-hierarchy.scopeNote: Does not exist independently; it requires cooperative delegation with a cryptographic commitment from both the GLEIF delegator and the QVI delegate.

cryptographic-primitives.definition: The foundational cryptographic data structures and encoding formats used in the vLEI Ecosystem, including Composable Event Streaming Representation (CESR) for text-binary encoding, Self-Addressing Identifiers (SAIDs) for content-based tamper-evident identifiers, cryptographic seals for anchoring data to key events, and distributed hash tables for AID discovery.
cryptographic-primitives.scopeNote: Does not function as a network address or locator; it is a content-based identifier for verification purposes.

security-infrastructure.definition: The security components of the KERI infrastructure including multi-signature schemes with weighted thresholds, trusted execution environments, hardware security modules, private key stores, escrow agents for key recovery, continuity policies, and mechanisms for detecting and recovering from private key compromise.
security-infrastructure.scopeNote: Does not define the total number of authorized representatives; a single-signer threshold applies only to sole-employee entities.

acdc.definition: A specification and data container format for verifiable credentials that supports cryptographic chaining through source links, composable JSON Schema, multiple serialization formats, Ricardian contracts, and chain-link confidentiality. Credentials exist in three forms: fully-expanded, fully-compressed, and schema-compressed, with rules sections for usage restrictions.
acdc.scopeNote: Does not refer to W3C Verifiable Credentials in general; ACDCs are a specific format with distinctive features including normative chaining support.

vlei-credential-types.definition: The hierarchy of vLEI Credential types in the ecosystem: the QVI vLEI Credential issued by GLEIF to authorize issuers, the Legal Entity vLEI Credential binding an entity's LEI to a KERI AID, and role credentials (OOR and ECR) binding persons to organizational or engagement roles.
vlei-credential-types.scopeNote: Does not grant authority to issue credentials outside the vLEI Ecosystem; revocation of this credential triggers a grace period and terminates the QVI's issuing capability.

credential-chain.definition: The cryptographic chain of trust for organizational identity in the vLEI ecosystem, implemented through ACDC source references and SAIDs, connecting GLEIF as the root of trust through Qualified vLEI Issuers to Legal Entities and their representatives, where revocation of any credential in the chain invalidates all downstream credentials.
credential-chain.scopeNote: Does not describe a trust hierarchy in the abstract; it is the concrete cryptographic linkage implemented through ACDC source references and SAIDs.

credential-lifecycle.definition: The full lifecycle of vLEI Credentials covering issuance, maintenance, and revocation processes. Issuance requires identity verification and LEI status checks. Maintenance ensures ongoing Active entity status and valid registration status. Revocation may be voluntary (holder-initiated) or involuntary (issuer or GLEIF-initiated due to non-compliance).
credential-lifecycle.scopeNote: Does not apply to Legal Entity or role-based vLEI Credentials directly; it is specific to the QVI vLEI Credential lifecycle.

vlei-credential-schema.definition: The JSON Schema 2020-12 compliant schema definitions for vLEI Credentials, each including a Self-Addressing Identifier (SAID) for immutability verification. Managed through the vLEI Credential Schema Registry maintained by GLEIF as the authoritative source, with schema versions following semantic versioning conventions.
vlei-credential-schema.scopeNote: Does not cover versioning of the KERI protocol or the EGF itself; applies specifically to credential schema versions.

credential-exchange.definition: The protocols and infrastructure for exchanging and verifying vLEI Credentials, including the Issuance and Presentation Exchange Protocol (IPEX) for credential presentation, proof requests from verifiers, graduated and contractually protected disclosure mechanisms, credential registries, transaction event logs, and credential wallets.
credential-exchange.scopeNote: Does not address credential issuance lifecycle management (creation, revocation); it specifically handles the presentation exchange mechanics.

gleif-authorized-representative.definition: Representatives of GLEIF authorized to perform identity verification, hold cryptographic keys, and approve key management operations. Includes Internal GARs managing the GLEIF Internal Delegated AID, and External GARs managing the GLEIF External Delegated AID, responsible for QVI credential issuance and QVI AID delegation.
gleif-authorized-representative.scopeNote: Does not interact directly with Legal Entities or their representatives; operates at the GLEIF-to-QVI level of the trust hierarchy.

qualified-vlei-issuer.definition: An organization that has been formally qualified by GLEIF through the vLEI Issuer Qualification Program and holds a valid QVI vLEI Credential, authorizing it to issue, maintain, and revoke Legal Entity, OOR, and ECR vLEI Credentials. Includes Candidate vLEI Issuers undergoing the qualification evaluation process.
qualified-vlei-issuer.scopeNote: Does not refer to any entity that issues verifiable credentials in general; it is specific to the GLEIF vLEI Ecosystem qualification.

altLabels: Delegated AID QVI Authorized Representative Lead
qvi-authorized-representative.definition: Representatives of a Qualified vLEI Issuer authorized to perform identity verification, credential issuance, and revocation operations. Requires at least two QARs operating in a multi-sig group, with a QAR Lead coordinating delegated AID creation and a mandatory dual-QAR workflow where separate QARs verify identity and co-sign credential issuance.
qvi-authorized-representative.scopeNote: Does not include Legal Entity Authorized Representatives (LARs) or Designated Authorized Representatives (DARs), which represent the Legal Entity.

legal-entity-representatives.definition: The authorized representatives acting on behalf of a Legal Entity in the vLEI Ecosystem. Designated Authorized Representatives (DARs) have signing authority to execute agreements and designate LARs. Legal Entity Authorized Representatives (LARs) manage day-to-day credential operations including issuance and revocation requests, with a LAR Lead initiating multi-sig group creation.
legal-entity-representatives.scopeNote: Does not include the authority to execute the vLEI Issuer Qualification Agreement, which is reserved for DARs.

oor-person.definition: A natural person who holds a formally recognized Official Organizational Role at a Legal Entity, such as a position defined in ISO 5009 (e.g., Chief Executive Officer, Board Director), whose identity and role must be verified before an OOR vLEI Credential can be issued. Requires explicit consent for public disclosure on the GLEIF LEI page.
oor-person.scopeNote: Does not include informal engagement-specific roles; the role must be verifiable through official public sources, business registry documents, or certified entity documentation.

ecr-person.definition: A natural person serving in an Engagement Context Role at a Legal Entity, representing a function within a specific engagement context such as a project-based or contractual capacity. Unlike Official Organizational Roles, engagement context roles are defined by the Legal Entity itself and do not require validation against public registries.
ecr-person.scopeNote: Does not require validation against public registries or ISO 5009 role lists; it is broader and more flexible than an Official Organizational Role.

qualification-program.definition: The comprehensive evaluation program required for organizations seeking to become Qualified vLEI Issuers, assessing financial, operational, and information technology capabilities through a structured self-assessment checklist and qualification manual, including conflict of interest evaluation and letters of assurance.
qualification-program.scopeNote: Covers initial qualification only; ongoing compliance is assessed through Annual vLEI Issuer Qualification.

annual-qualification.definition: The recurring and exceptional qualification processes for Qualified vLEI Issuers, including Annual vLEI Issuer Qualification conducted on each anniversary date and Extraordinary Qualification triggered when documentation is no longer current, plus GLEIF's verification and audit rights over QVI internal controls and operations.
annual-qualification.scopeNote: Does not include the initial qualification process for Candidate vLEI Issuers or Extraordinary vLEI Issuer Qualification.

identity-verification.definition: The combined process of Identity Assurance and Identity Authentication required before vLEI Credential issuance. Identity Assurance verifies real-world identity to at least IAL2 (NIST 800-63A) or via approved digital identity schemes. Identity Authentication cryptographically verifies control of an AID through challenge-response protocols, spot checks, and signing authority verification.
identity-verification.scopeNote: Only schemes at High or Substantial Level of Assurance are accepted; does not include commercial or private identity verification services.

oobi-protocol.definition: The out-of-band introduction and interaction protocol in KERI for bootstrapping trust between parties through real-time sessions with audio and video, during which participants exchange Autonomic Identifiers via OOBI discovery mechanisms and perform cryptographic authentication through unique Challenge Messages that must be signed and returned.
oobi-protocol.scopeNote: Does not itself authenticate an identifier; it provides the initial introduction that must be followed by cryptographic verification.

risk-assessment.definition: The vLEI Risk Assessment framework categorizing risks by governance layer (Ecosystem, Credential, Provider, Utility) and trust area (Governance, Availability, Security, Privacy, Confidentiality, Processing Integrity), covering Governing Authority, QVI, Verifier, Credential Registry, and Utility risk categories with treatment recommendations.
risk-assessment.scopeNote: Does not cover QVI-specific, Verifier, Utility, or Legal Entity risk categories.

altLabels: Qualified vLEI Issuer Service Level Agreement
service-level-management.definition: The operational management framework for the vLEI Ecosystem covering service level agreements between GLEIF and Qualified vLEI Issuers, service level targets, breach handling, escalation management, incident management, disaster recovery, service continuity processes, the communications portal, and the challenge mechanism for Legal Entity data.
service-level-management.scopeNote: Changes to contact details do not require prior GLEIF approval.

trustmark.definition: A mark provided by GLEIF to a Qualified vLEI Issuer upon successful qualification, subject to specific terms of use governing display on the QVI's website, prohibition against implying GLEIF association beyond qualified services, and liquidated damages for non-compliance. Must be removed upon termination or failure to complete annual qualification.
trustmark.scopeNote: Does not convey any intellectual property rights in vLEIs and must not be provided to third parties.

altLabels: Legal Entity Official Organizational Role vLEI Credential
oor-vlei-credential.definition: A vLEI role credential binding a natural person to a specific Official Organizational Role at a Legal Entity, validated against external official sources or ISO 5009 role lists. Issued through a credential chain requiring a QVI OOR Authorization credential from a LAR and an OOR Authorization credential from the issuing QVI.
oor-vlei-credential.scopeNote: Does not cover informal or engagement-specific roles, which are addressed by the ECR vLEI Credential; does not assert trustworthiness of the Legal Entity.

altLabels: Legal Entity Engagement Context Role vLEI Credential
ecr-vlei-credential.definition: A vLEI role credential binding a natural person to a specific Engagement Context Role at a Legal Entity, which may be issued either by a Qualified vLEI Issuer or directly by the Legal Entity itself. Supports privacy-preserving graduated disclosure of personally identifying information and requires a QVI ECR Authorization credential for QVI-issued variants.
ecr-vlei-credential.scopeNote: Does not cover official organizational roles validated against public registries, which are addressed by the OOR vLEI Credential; does not assert trustworthiness of the Legal Entity.

altLabels: Qualified vLEI Issuer Authorization vLEI Credential
qvi-auth-vlei-credential.definition: A family of authorization credentials issued by Legal Entity Authorized Representatives to Qualified vLEI Issuers, comprising QVI OOR AUTH and QVI ECR AUTH variants, that provide secure instruction and authorization for the issuance and revocation of specific vLEI Role Credentials. Part of the internal credential chain, not presented to external verifiers.
qvi-auth-vlei-credential.scopeNote: Does not itself serve as a publicly presentable vLEI Credential; it is part of the internal credential chain that authorizes QVI actions.

vlei-reporting-api.definition: An API provided by GLEIF through which Qualified vLEI Issuers must report each issuance and revocation event of vLEI Credentials, enabling GLEIF to maintain accurate public records on LEI pages on gleif.org that display entity LEI information and associated credential details.
vlei-reporting-api.scopeNote: Does not serve as the authoritative source for credential verification; it is an informational display that reflects reported credential status.

vlei-software.definition: Open-source software sponsored by GLEIF with capabilities for vLEI Credential issuance, presentation, identifier and key management, credential revocation, and supporting functions that Qualified vLEI Issuers must install, test, and implement as part of their vLEI Ecosystem operations.

assurance-dimensions.definition: The three assurance dimensions within the Trust Assurance Framework: Specification Assurance ensuring requirements are formally documented, Conformance Assurance confirming compliance through evaluation processes such as annual qualification, and Performance Assurance enforcing requirements through technical architecture including KERI and vLEI software.

qvi-self-issuance.definition: The practice whereby a Qualified vLEI Issuer issues a Legal Entity vLEI Credential and OOR vLEI Credentials to itself as a Legal Entity, subject to GLEIF oversight. GLEIF may require QVIs to contract with third-party QVIs for their own credentials after a specified future deadline.
qvi-self-issuance.scopeNote: Does not extend to ECR vLEI Credentials; GLEIF may require QVIs to contract with third-party QVIs for their own credentials after a specified date.
